item.title: The power of paths
item.description: A path is a way to something. It’s how we go from what we know, and where we are, to what we want to know, and where we want to go.

item.title: The new definitions & difficulty system
item.description: We are excited to announce two new systems on the blog. These are intended to help using the blog easier, and for us to become a better resource for people of all skill levels!

item.title: Datastructures in C++
item.description: By now you should have a decent understanding of classes and objects. If not, go check out our blog post on the topic to see what I’m talking about.

item.title: Using User Interfaces in VBA
item.description: See previous post Overview User Interfaces (UIs) are important to communicate the program to the user. UIs are the gap between the program and the user.

item.title: Making categories simpler
item.description: Why is a wolf different than a jellyfish? There are obvious differences, but how do we categorize something as more wolfey, or more jellyfishy?

item.title: Intro To Node.js
item.description: If you’ve been learning or reading about web development, you’ve probably heard about Node.js. In this article series, we’ll help you get started using Node by building a homework-tracking application and providing you with all the information and tools you need to develop your own projects using Node.

item.title: Review
item.description: This session consists of a kahoot review game, and time to work on projects with your mentors.

item.title: The web beyond websites
item.description: In this session we will talk about some of the other uses for web technologies beyond just basic websites, and have an extended Q & A

item.title: Review
item.description: This session consists of a kahoot review game, and time to work on projects with your mentors.

item.title: It's caches all the way down
item.description: Nostalgia can be very powerful, looking back at the world can make people feel warm and fuzzy inside. However, one thing people are not nostalgic of is how long computers used to take to do things.

item.title: Bonus Topics
item.description: This session introduces students to Collisions.

item.title: Security
item.description: Now that we’ve built a backend, it’s time to look at how to secure it!

item.title: Best Practices, and Level Design
item.description: In this session, we willl cover good coding practice, level design and adding bullets to our game.

item.title: General Syntax Visual Basic for Applications (VBA)
item.description: See previous post The goal of this blog post is to give an overview of VBA syntax and show some features of VBA’s built-in code editor.

item.title: Functions
item.description: This session introduces students to functions. Functions help split our code into small reusable chunks so you don’t need to write the same thing multiple times.

item.title: Intro to backend and API's
item.description: In this session we will look at how to build out a backend, get data from users, and how to retrieve data from external sources!

item.title: Problem Solving, Enemies, And Starting Your Game
item.description: In this session we will cover techniques for solving problems, implementing enemies, and how to start your game

item.title: Classes and Objects (C++)
item.description: What is a Class? At this point, you should have a good understanding of the basic variables in programming, as well as how to use loops and functions effectively.

item.title: Loops and User Input
item.description: In this session we explore loops in more depth and introduce new inputs. Different types of inputs allow for us to interact with the user in more ways.

item.title: Basic networking & Deploying sites
item.description: In this session we will look at how to deploy sites, how basic networking works, and the basics of CI/CD (automation) systems

item.title: Introduction to Physics and Collision
item.description: In this session we will cover more the logical implementation techniques for physics and collisions

item.title: Stealing Like a Developer
item.description: No one writes all their own code. We always build on the shoulders of the people that came before us. But how do we do this responsibly, and legally?

item.title: Lists and an Introduction to Loops
item.description: This session introduces lists and loops. Lists store multiple values while loops repeat a section of code a certain number of times.

item.title: Markup languages, templating & SSG's
item.description: In this session we cover the basics of markup languages, how to get data into our HTML and static site generators to create sites that are easier to maintain

item.title: Introduction to Inheritance and Sprites
item.description: In this session we will cover more methods, inheritance and PyGame sprites - applications and usecases.

item.title: Intro to Visual Basic for Applications (VBA)
item.description: VBA is a programming language that was created by Microsoft to help program inside their office applications. These office applications have helped students, teachers, office workers, and many others complete tasks quickly.

item.title: If-Statements and Logical Operators
item.description: In this session we will focus on if/else statements as well as logical and relational operators. These operators are used in if/else statements to apply limits and restraints to our code.

item.title: Advanced JS, Vendoring (Using other people's code)
item.description: This session will cover how to use existing code effectively, and legally. As well as some more advanced Javascript techniques

item.title: Introduction to Methods and Events
item.description: In this session we will cover methods and PyGame events - applications and usecases.

item.title: Custom Web Fonts
item.description: Custom fonts can be a suprisingly difficult topic to tackle, especially on the web. We’re going to try to make it easier by giving you the info you need to start working with them properly on the web!

item.title: Operators and Making Objects Move
item.description: In this session we will build on the types and uses of variables and arithmetic operators. Proper variable and operator use is crucial to the simplicity and maintainability of our code.

item.title: Advanced CSS, Bootstrap & Javascript
item.description: This session will cover using advanced CSS, and CSS frameworks as well as introducing javascript!

item.title: Introduction to Classes and Objects
item.description: In this session we will cover the basics of Object Oriented Programming - creating classes and objects.

item.title: How to cheat at CSS
item.description: CSS is the language of design on the web. It’s used to control how everything looks. The styling of this text, how the article metadata (tags, authors etc) above this looks, everything.

item.title: How to Write Pseudocode
item.description: Perhaps you have taken a computer science course, and you heard the term “pseudocode” used at some point. If you have ever wondered what this is, here is the guide for you.

item.title: Introduction to Python
item.description: In this session we will give an intro to the coding platform we use and the basics of python. These basics will be the fundamental building blocks of all of our code!

item.title: HTML, CSS, basic design
item.description: This session will help cover the basics of how webpages work, building basic pages, and a bit about design!

item.title: Introduction to Python and Pygame
item.description: In this session we will review basic coding concepts and give an introduction into pygame.

item.title: Taking your HTML elements further
item.description: When you begin learning about HTML, CSS and Javascript there is a belief many people hold that HTML is pretty useless.

item.title: Introduction to Schulich Ignite
item.description: In this session we will give an intro to the coding platform we use and Schulich Ignite!

item.title: Introduction to Schulich Ignite
item.description: In this session we will give an intro to the coding platform we use and Schulich Ignite!

item.title: Introduction to Schulich Ignite
item.description: This session is here to have everyone setup their development environments and get introduced to the course!

item.title: Pointers and References in C++
item.description: In many high level coding languages, The idea of a pointer either doesn’t exist, or is hidden from the programmer’s use.

item.title: The Dangers of CDN's
item.description: CDN’s are used a lot in web development to make things faster, and easier. But with everything there are pros and cons.

item.title: Updates to the Schulich ignite blog
item.description: Introducing the new Blog and Showcase Currently, this blog is being used to give updates about upcoming events for the club, and awards.

item.title: Winter 2021 Gala
item.description: Last weekend, Schulich Ignite celebrated the end of our Winter 2021 sessions with a Gala Event! The Gala Event celebrated the accomplishments of over 300 students who attended our workshops this semester.

item.title: Club of the Year!
item.description: Schulich Ignite is excited to announce that we have received the 2020-2021 SU Club of the Year Award! Thank you to the Student’s Union for the recognition, we are honoured to be the recipients of the award this year.

item.title: Fall 2020 Gala
item.description: Schulich Ignite celebrated the end of our fall sessions with a Gala! At the Gala, we congratulated our students for completing the workshop.

item.title: Collaboration with Information Security Club
item.description: We are excited for our collaboration with the Information Security Club which will be happening in the last week of November!
An application program interface is basically a system that allows you to use other people’s code and/or systems. There are lots of things people mean when they say API:
Classes are a programming construct that allows you to organize your code. Essentially you create a class which acts as a kind of template which you can then create instances/objects out of.
Collections are a data type that is used to hold multiple other data types. For example lets say you wanted to keep track of all of the names of items in a player inventory.

In programming we don’t always want to execute the same code. Sometimes we want to execute code based on something. We might want to check if someone has a premium account before allowing them to access a song, or check if they’re in a certain country etc.
Everything starts with data in programming. If you want to be able to do anything you need to be able to work with data.
Encoding just means a way to take a set of information in one format, and convert or represent it to another format.
Functions are a way to reuse code efficiently. It allows you to define a set of steps of code that should be run when the function is “called”, along with a name.

HTTP (HyperText Transfer Protocol) is the way most of the web communicates. It’s the system that governs how your computer talks to servers around the world to retrieve webpages, talk to your online calendar, and even send messages in point of sales systems.

Loops are a concept in programming that allows you to run some code for a defined number of times. This means if you have an operation you want to run 1000 times, or maybe run some code for every user in a database, or show a menu until someone makes a choice in a game, loops are what you want.

Packages allow you to break up code into chunks that make it easier to understand what each piece is doing. How this works is up to the language, typically there will be a defined file/folder structure that is used to define packages.
Many times when you are writing a program you will need to find something. For example you will need to open a file to read it’s contents, or send users a page based on their URL.
When working with code you will inevitably want to store some information. To store information we use variables. Variables are basically labels we can use to refer to information more easily.
When we visit a page on the web we don’t tend to think too much about what makes up the page.
Our sessions are completely free for all. All that we ask is that you bring your enthusiasm and passion for programming!
Yes! If you would like to be grouped with your friends who are also joining the program, simply list their names in the sign up survey, and we will do the rest!
Through the Schulich Ignite program, you will be able to develop as aprogrammer all the way from gaining basic coding skills all the way to becoming a proficient and certified software developer.
We are always recruiting for mentors, content-developers, and commisoners! Join our mailing list for details about when we begin recruitment

We will have two formats for our sessions this semester: Hybrid: We will have the ENG G 203 room booked in the Schulich School of Engineering Building,on the University of Calgary Campus, for students that have access to this form of transport.

Our programs are aimed at ages between 11-21 (this is not enforced though), our 3 courses range from an gentle introduction to programming in python, to advanced programming methodologies with the aid of Object-Oriented programming, and lastly our Web-development course which builds on the advanced programming methodologies in the field of Websites and many more cool technologies which will help you build and maintain your website!
Why Code? Coding helps you develop many valuable skills! Problem solving: Programming teaches you how to efficiently break down complex tasks into smaller and more manageable operations.
> 1000 students have completed our workshops since our conception in 2016. > 80% of participants can see themselves pursuing engineering or jobs in tech related fields after attending our sessions.
My name is Abod Abbas and I am the President at Schulich Ignite. I am responsible for managing and monitoring the club, alongside being a mentor.

Hello! My name is Anna Lee and I am the VP Finance at Schulich Ignite. I am responsible for managing the club’s finances, finding and working with stakeholders to support the club, and purchasing supplies needed for club operations and our sessions.
Hello My name is Arya Patel, I am studying Software Engineering and Biomedical Engineering currently into my second year . I work in the executive team as a Junior VP External.
